keywords: We measure the radial number density profiles of these satellites as a function of host properties, finding trends consistent with previous spectroscopic studies. Our results demonstrate the power of deep learning methods for efficiently selecting low-redshift satellite systems from wide-area imaging surveys, enabling statistical studies of satellite distributions and environmental effects on galaxy evolution at an unprecedented scale

title: The DECam local volume exploration survey: Overview and first data release
keywords: aperture photometry for over 1.5 billion astronomical sources across more than 6,000 square degrees of the sky. DELVE DR1 includes imaging data from four optical/near-infrared filters (g, r, i, z), with a median 5σ point-source depth of g = 23.5, r = 23.0, i = 22.5, and z = 22.0 mag. This release offers a comprehensive catalog of faint sources, including low-surface-brightness galaxies, star clusters, and resolved stellar populations, providing valuable data for studying the evolution of faint galaxies, satellite populations, and stellar substructures in the Local Volume. We also highlight the ongoing work to enhance DELVE’s coverage and deepen our understanding of the relationship between galaxy environments and their evolution
